title: 104_s867
content: The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995, also known as the "Act," increases unified estate and gift tax credits for family enterprises. The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995 increases unified estate and gift tax credits for family enterprises by allowing an additional credit for family enterprise property included in the decedent's gross estate. The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995 increases estate and gift tax credits for family enterprises by adding a credit for family enterprise property. This credit applies to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1995, and gifts made after the same date. The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995 increases the annual gift tax exclusion by allowing an additional exclusion for gifts of family enterprise property. This amendment applies to gifts made after December 31, 1995. The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995 introduces a new provision for family enterprise property under SEC. 2040A. The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995 introduces a provision for family enterprise property in SEC. 2040A. This section defines family enterprise property as an interest in property used for farming or other business purposes, with specific ownership requirements. The value included in the decedent's gross estate for such property is determined based on certain criteria. The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995 introduces a provision for family enterprise property in SEC. 2040A. Family enterprise property is defined as an interest in property used for farming or business purposes, with ownership restrictions. Limited partnership interests are excluded from this definition. The tax treatment of dispositions and failure to use for qualifying purposes is also outlined, imposing additional estate tax if the property is disposed of within 10 years after the decedent's death. The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995 introduces a provision for family enterprise property in SEC. 2040A. If an individual or their family ceases active management of such property, an additional estate tax is imposed. The amount of the additional tax is based on the excess of the estate tax liability attributable to the interest in family enterprise property over the reduced estate tax liability. The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995 introduces a provision for family enterprise property in SEC. 2040A, defining "active management" and applying rules similar to other sections of the Internal Revenue Code. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The National Family Enterprise Preservation Act of 1995 introduces a provision for family enterprise property in SEC. 2040A, with amendments to the valuation of certain farm real property under Section 2032A(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code. Effective date for both provisions is for estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1995.
